fields.value: Public Warnings and Evacuations: A Study of the 2009 California Station Fire

authorAffiliation.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Response to Terrorism (START), University of Maryland.
National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Response to Terrorism (START), University of Maryland.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
A survey of residents of the area impacted by a large-scale 2009 wildfire revealed that just over 60% of respondents who received an evacuation order during this fire actually evacuated from their home. The focus of the survey was to understand the impact of public warnings on the behaviors and actions of individuals in the midst of a natural disaster.   The survey instrument and interview protocol were designed by the project research team to gauge several factors, including how respondents were individually impacted by the Station Fire; their attitudes toward formal evacuation messages and procedures as spearheaded by local, state, and government entities; how they responded to said evacuation messages and procedures; what they perceive to the most effective media for dispensing emergency evacuation information; as well as standard demographic questions. These analyses reveal that frequency, communication channels, and content of public warnings, such as evacuation orders, have a significant impact on public protective-action
taking.

fields.value: Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: The survey respondents correspond demographically to a community affected by the Station Fire but not exactly.;

producerName.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism

distributorName.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism

value: Those affected by disasters associated with orders to evacuate residential areas.

fields.value: The Public Opinion Research Laboratory at the University of North Florida (a twenty-seven station polling facility located in Jacksonville, Florida) conducted a telephone survey of residents of Los Angeles County and the vicinity, targeting specific areas that were most impacted by the August 2009 Station Fire. Respondents were identified through the use of a Random-Digit-Dial (RDD) list provided by Marketing Systems Group and Genesys Sampling, in which all landline telephone numbers within the sampling area have an equal chance of selection. This survey employed a probability sample of adult respondents aged eighteen and older; in each selected household, one adult person was interviewed using random selection procedures. The survey instrument and interview protocol was designed by the project research team to gauge several factors, including how respondents were individually impacted by the Station Fire; their attitudes toward formal evacuation messages and procedures as spearheaded by local, state, and government entities; how they responded to said evacuation messages and procedures; what they perceive to the most effective media for dispensing emergency evacuation information; as well as standard demographic questions. The survey contained sixty questions (per respondent) and seven of these question were demographic in nature.
